items.title: ‘Very unique’: Pod of killer whales seen rubbing bellies on rocks off B.C.'s Sunshine Coast
items.summary_auto: People at a beach on the Sunshine Cost were left awestruck after watching a pod of killer whales swim close to the shore. Amongst all of the different killer whale populations around the world, few have been observed performing the rare activity, says cetology expert.

items.title: Canada's cheaper, cleaner and lower-risk oil can rival a resurgent Venezuela, Carney says
At least 25 people killed in Iranian economic protests, rights groups say
items.summary_auto: At least 25 people have been killed in Iran during the first nine days of protests that started in the bazaar of Tehran over the plunging value of the currency and soaring inflation, according to rights groups.

items.title: Swiss officials can't explain why bar hadn't received fire safety inspection in 6 years ahead of deadly blaze
items.summary_auto: Fire safety inspections hadn't been carried out for several years at the bar where a fire that broke out at a New Year's party left 40 people dead and over 100 injured, local authorities said Tuesday.

items.title: 'It's like on Amazon': Illegal drugs advertised online, delivered by Canada Post
Amnesty International joins fight for Nova Scotia dump site cleanup and safe water
items.summary_auto: An international organization that often finds itself at the centre of human rights conflicts in developing countries has turned its attention to a small town in southwest Nova Scotia.

items.title: Cheaper obesity medications could come to Canada this summer, as Health Canada reviews generics
items.summary_auto: In Canada, the patent for some semaglutide drugs has expired, paving the way for the country to become the first to offer cheaper generic versions of medications like Ozempic and Wegovy to people with prescriptions. Pharmaceutical experts say this could take some time.

items.title: More oil production in Venezuela could hurt Canada's oilpatch
items.summary_auto: A regime change in Venezuela could both help that country regain its former prominence as an oil producer and pose a threat to Canada’s industry, which is producing record amounts of oil and is expected to continue to grow for several more years.

items.title: Trump's Greenland annexation threats overshadow Ukraine security conference
items.summary_auto: The capture and planned prosecution of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro under U.S. law rattled European leaders gathered in Paris on the eve of planned meetings over specific security guarantees for Ukraine.

items.title: Former Manitoba NDP MLA files defamation claim against premier, 2 other MLAs, over Nygard association
items.summary_auto: Manitoba Independent MLA Mark Wasyliw has filed a defamation lawsuit against Premier Wab Kinew and two other members of Kinew's NDP government, claiming they associated the defence lawyer-turned-MLA with convicted criminal Peter Nygard as an excuse to kick him out of the party.

items.title: B.C. jobs in high demand: Why 2026 may be the best time to learn a trade
items.summary_auto: Amid Prime Minister Mark Carney’s push for nation-building projects and uncertainty around  AI’s impact on the job market, an advocate for British Columbia’s construction industry says there’s no better time to consider a career in the trades.

items.title: Vancouver area home sales hit lowest level in more than two decades in 2025
items.summary_auto: Greater Vancouver recorded its lowest annual home sales total in more than two decades in 2025, capping a year that saw weak buyer demand, rising inventory and easing prices, according to new data from Greater Vancouver Realtors.

items.title: Eva Schloss, Holocaust survivor and stepsister of Anne Frank, dead at 96
items.summary_auto: Auschwitz survivor Eva Schloss, the stepsister of teenage diarist Anne Frank and a tireless educator about the horrors of the Holocaust, has died. She was 96.

items.title: 'We are waiting for something better to come': Venezuelans face the future of their country
items.summary_auto: Venezuelans travelling over the Colombian-Venezuelan border say people in the country are trying to live normal lives in the face of an uncertain future.

items.title: Canada tops Finland to claim bronze at world junior hockey championship; Sweden wins gold
items.summary_auto: Zayne Parekh had a goal and an assist to set a new record for points by a Canadian defenceman at a world junior hockey championship as the country salvaged a bronze medal with a 6-3 victory over Finland on Monday.

items.title: With Olympics near, return to full health trumps potential milestone win for Mikaël Kingsbury
items.summary_auto: Canadian freestyle skier and reigning Olympic silver medallist Mikaël Kingsbury says he's nearing full health from a left groin injury while preparing for a return to World Cup moguls this week in Val St-Côme, Que.

items.title: World leaders push back against U.S. in wake of Maduro's ouster
items.summary_auto: Leaders in Greenland, Mexico and Colombia are asserting their respective nations' sovereignty and pushing back on pressure from Washington after it removed Nicolás Maduro from power in Venezuela over the weekend.

items.title: Venezuelans wait anxiously as their country's future hangs in the balance, says resident
items.summary_auto: A strange lull has taken over the capital of Venezuela as people wait to find out what the future holds for their country, says Caracas resident Benigno Alarcón Deza.

items.title: Lawsuit alleges 3 Denny’s workers in Kamloops, B.C., misappropriated $500K in tips
items.summary_auto: A civil suit filed in the Supreme Court of B.C. accuses three Denny's workers of misappropriating more than $500,000 in tips from the restaurant chain while working at a Kamloops location between 2023 and 2025.

items.title: Uncertainty looms in Cuba after the capture of president of Venezuela, Cuba's closest ally
items.summary_auto: Cuban officials on Monday lowered flags before dawn to mourn 32 security officers they say were killed in the U.S. weekend strike in Venezuela, Cuba's closest ally, as residents of the island nation wonder what the capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro means for their future.

items.title: Venezuela's collapse, Trump’s military buildup and Maduro's capture: How did we get here?
items.summary_auto: Now that we're at a crisis point — with the United Nations saying U.S. President Donald Trump's weekend invasion of Venezuela contravened its charter and with Nicolas Maduro appearing in a U.S. court — it's a good time to review what led to this moment.

items.title: Impaired drivers in Ontario face automatic, harsher penalties under new rules now in effect
items.summary_auto: New rules and increased penalties for impaired driving took effect this month across Ontario, after the province made amendments to the Highway Traffic Act. Advocacy groups say more can be done to curb impaired drivers, but overall, the changes are positive.

items.title: Rare prosecution of a police officer gets underway in connection to Uvalde, Texas, school shooting
items.summary_auto: A Texas judge seated a jury Monday in the trial of a former school police officer in Uvalde who was part of the hesitant law enforcement response to one of the worst school shootings in U.S. history and has been charged with failing to protect children from the gunman.

items.title: 10 people found guilty of cyberbullying French first lady Brigitte Macron
items.summary_auto: A Paris court has found 10 people guilty of cyberbullying France's first lady, Brigitte Macron, by spreading false online claims about her gender and sexuality, including allegations that she was born male.
